vectorData.altText: Note: Sympathetic ganglia are bilaterally paired, and each serves its own side of the body.

The accompanying diagram shows a wedge of the spinal cord at the T10 level and the nerves and ganglia associated with it. It highlights the distribution of sympathetics from this representative segment of the spinal cord between T1 and L2 to its associated dermatome. 
Recall that the axons of somatic motor neurons emerge from the spinal cord to synapse directly on their target skeletal muscle     . This is not the case for sympathetic motor neurons. 
In the accompanying diagram, follow the sympathetic axon (solid blue line) from its multipolar cell body in the spinal cord, through the ventral root and into the spinal nerve. From there, follow the axon through the white      ramus communicans      to the sympathetic ganglion. This sympathetic neuron is termed the “preganglionic neuron”, and its fibre the “preganglionic axon”     .
pre = before; the preganglionic neuron comes carries information into the sympathetic ganglion from the spinal cord
the “white ramus communicans” is white because its axon is coated by myelin, a lipid material that makes it appear white in fresh tissue.

On one side, notice that the somatic motor axon passes into the dorsal ramus to synapse onto intrinsic back muscles, the muscles in the paravertebral       region of the back. 
On the other side, notice that the somatic motor axon passes into the ventral ramus to synapse onto any and all other muscles in the body wall and limbs. 
Sensory axons accompany motor axons through both, to monitor receptors in the corresponding body regions.
para = on either side; these are the muscles on either side of the vertebral column

The accompanying diagram shows a wedge of the spinal cord, the nerves and ganglia associated with it, and the synapse between somatic motor neurons and their target skeletal muscle. The contact between a somatic motor neuron and its target muscle occurs at the neuromuscular junction, or NMJ.
On both sides of the illustration, trace the axon of the multipolar somatic motor neuron (blue) from its cell body in the spinal cord, through the ventral root and spinal nerve.
